Some stand out positives:
Fantastic game with a lot of progression systems to keep the player pushing forward. If you ever feel stuck or struggling, you can grind some of the meta-progression to get stronger.
Steam Workshop Support with a huge amount of QOL mods; if you find any annoyances within the game, there is likely a mod to remove/adjust it.
Difficulty options to adjust if you find the game too easy or too difficult.
Amazing sound design, can be very immersive. Sometimes you get 7-8 NPC's all fighting each other with rockets and explosions going off in the distance.

Very excited for the future of PvE extraction shooters after playing through Duckov.

I was planning on playing other games but I can't stop playing this game.
[h2]Gameplay	[/h2]
[h3]The loop[/h3]
The gameplay is very easy to learn, just put your cursor on the enemy's head for headshots and get behind sandbags for cover and shoot over them or use the roll just like in Dark Souls to avoid damage.
Despite being simple, it still is challenging as you won't always fight in optimal conditions and the enemy variety will often catch you off guard.
The gameplay loop is usually like this :
-You go out
-You kill enemies and loot containers
-You complete quests
-You extract
This can be as long or as short as you want since there are multiple extraction spots, one that's litteraly where you enter from, allowing you to go on low stakes run if you feel unprepared.

[h3]The maps[/h3]
The game is split into multiple different big areas linked to each other with plenty of shortcuts that reminded me of Dark Souls 1 where your starting zone expands naturally as you unlock shortcuts that allow you to reach different places faster.

[h3]NPCs[/h3]
Once you get used to the loop, you can see the actual depth of the game as you start unlocking stuff, the  game kinda works like terraria where NPCs will join you either once you complete their quests or once you build their structures. These NPCs will provide you with an easier access to some materials for crafting as well as more quests with more rewards.
The game also rewards very long term planning as you can see the requirements for every upgrade from the get-go allowing you to mark important items that you shouldn't sell wihch makes progression a lot smoother.

[h3]Progression[/h3]
As you raid and extract and complete quests, you will get experience, this experience will allow you to level up which unlocks access to new upgrades both for your character but also for your base facilities which can be upgraded to provide even better services.
All these upgrades require materials and money which means you'll need to either choose carefully how you spend your money or you'll just need to do some extra quests and raids to get more money and materials. Given that you have no time pressure you could just sit back and farm towards something you really want and complete side quests along the way.

[h3]Sound design[/h3]
The sound design is great and its inclusion into gameplay makes it feel all the more satisfying as you hear gunshots in the distance indicating a skirmish between two rival factions which also indicates where you can find loot.
But it goes much deeper than that as the sound the player makes is also very important to the gameplay.
For instance, if you walk you make noise and if you run you make even more noise, making enemies aware of your presence that much faster. However if you aim by holding right click you will also sneak which makes no noise and allows you to sneak past enemies provided they don't see you.
But you can also use the sound to your advantage as enemies will check out any noise that they hear, allowing you to stay behind cover and bait them into traps like mines, bear traps or just a regular ambush where you engage at your prefered distance.
The sound enemies make is of equal importance as it allows you to know not only where they are but also their state as much like in Metal Gear, enemies have a sound for being on alert and a sound for engaging in combat allowing you to gather intel without even seeing the enemy. Also hearing the enemy shoot their guns obviously tells you what weapon they are using which allows you to engage at long range for instance if they use a close range weapon like a shotgun.

[h2]Conclusion/TL;DR[/h2]

All in all a very addicting game with a simple gameplay loop that can be stretched over a long period if you want with a difficulty that can be set at any time through options and gameplay.

Its a very solid game but I just can't recommend it right now for a few major reasons.

The blueprints are trapped behind a green key carded area in JLab. Despite running JLab over 50 times, I have yet to find a green key card. I tried cheeseing the vendor as well over 2 dozen times, running back and forth and reloading, no dice. This is incredibly stupid. Please increase the drop rates of these key cards, or give us alternative means to craft these stupid goggles.

Second, I am beyond tired of having max gear only to dumpstered by some mini-boss where my health goes from 100 to 0 in .05 seconds, the game hitches while it tries to load the death animation, everything freezes, and I die. Like, you only have 2 means of defense. Armor and dodge rolls. Armor is set value. You have it or you dont. And you cant dodge roll out of the way of half these mini-bosses. Misel one shots you if you are anywhere even remotely near a rocket exploding. The dumb jukebox just fire hoses you with bullets with no window to counter. And the Wanderers with Special AP will kill you in 3 bullets of a 5 bullet burst. Its so ridiculously overtuned I can't even believe I have to post this. 

Lastly, item RNG in general needs to be completely rebalanced or with alternative (or guaranteed) methods of obtaining certain progression specific items. Yogurts, Homemade Candy, Cake... these are needed constantly and yet despite over 35 hours in the game, I think I've found 2 pieces of cake. Need a uPhone? Good luck. Never, not once, have I found a uPhone. The rarity on some of these items needs to be completely overhauled. 

So many minor gripes that just add up too. Silencers dont seem to do anything, worthless. The game willingly lets you launch into a storm without a warning despite you having no protective gear. The game also doesnt tell you absolutely KEY information that you will only find on Google because a million other people have hit the same wall (ie, you can craft every other medkit except large for some unknown reason?)

It just needs a lot of re-tuning and a complete re-distribution of its loot table with more indicators what you really need and where to find it. Until then, this is just a frustrating slot of fetch quests and absolutely crawling degrees of progression masked behind a cute facade.

This game is pure frustration.  Every mission is a fetch quest or "Kill X person with Y specific weapon you have to grind more to get."  You collect tons of vendor trash, but don't know what you need to save to complete future missions, and have very limited backpack and storage space.  There are few maps, and they are poorly designed, with lots of blind corners leading no where and endless backtracking.  The baseline "normal" difficulty is very difficult.  (Though you can customize it to lower the difficulty as much as you want, this turns off achievements).  By default if you're killed and don't retrieve your stuff from the map on the first try, you lose your items (with limited safety boxes on your pet dog), and thus can lose a lot of your progression.  It seems like this game is targeted to a very specific fandom of players who like insanely difficult survival games.  But if you're a casual player like me who stumbled across it and bought it because it had a lot of positive buzz online, you will be deeply disappointed in your purchase.  I kept playing until I beat it, thinking it would somehow get better, but it does not.  Endless grind.  Do not buy this game unless you've played other similar survival crafting games and love the genre.
